May 13 2009 	An absolute dream I only wish I could do it all again!	My boyfriend booked this hotel on expedia and got a very reasonable price to stay for a week over the New Year 2009. I was unaware that he was planning to propose to me, and he had contacted the hotel in advance. He organised a limosiune to drive us to the hotel, which was magical and when we arrived, the concierge immediately took care of our bags (for a fee of course!). Then, to make things even more flawless, the desk attendant upgraded us free of charge to a superior bedroom, which was beautiful and spacious. The decor in the lobby was stunning, and everything was very grand- christmas tree, chandelier etc... Staff were pleasant, and cleaning staff were wonderfully efficient!). They also recommended that we hire one of their black cabs to return us to the airport, which was more comfortable and efficient than a regular yellow cab, and only cost 10 dollars more! good choice!! There is a wonderful steakhouse called Morton's as your exit the main entrance and turn right and walk straight for a block, we celebrated here and although it was very expensive, I have never tasted food like it!!! The location was fantastically close to everything (just a block away from the diamond district where I chose my engagement ring!), and the bed was perfect after a long day sight seeing. We will definitely return to this hotel!

May 13 2009 	Here's more detail - give the Roosevelt a try more nice than naughty.	After reading a number of reviews, I stayed at the Roosevelt Hotel, and now I understand some of the remarks. There are some very, very nice things about this hotel - and some not so great - but don't pass this hotel by - it's a good value in an otherwise very expensive area of mid-town.Here is more detail for those first timers that I had wished I knew prior to my stay...Location, location, location as mentioned, near Grand Central at 45th and Madison - nearby is Times Square, and loads of subway choices, restaurants, shopping, and plentiful taxicabs.As everyone says, the lobby is beautiful, and has a nice seating area if you are waiting for friends. It's fun to people watch and see the bustle. There's a bellhop and concierge service. There's a coffee bar (agree with other posts you can do better elsewhere, but in a rush it's OK).As opposed to some comments, my check-in experience was very good, and my person was quite nice. I had booked open choice two or one bed; I was asked if a King bed was acceptable, and I agreed. I think now a room with two beds might get you a slightly larger room, but for 1 person the room I had was fine.There are a number of elevators in the lobby, but it is hard to figure out if they are going down, or up - and the punch buttons are only on either side of the bank with no button in the middle. It was actually funny to watch newbies (like me) first look in the middle for the button, and then search the bank for the buttons on the side. At busy times there was a bit of a wait.The room I received (a king on the 7th floor) was at the end of two very long corridors. My room took some time to find. This is a big place, with odd numbered rooms on one side, even on the other. Note that the room number signs don't tell you this, I had to figure it out after wandering down various hallways.Something about the older style reminded me of the Overlook Hotel from the Shining - but thankfully without the horror. The hallways were clean, sort of like grandma's house with a little old musty smell and flowery carpeting with a few stains here and there. The musty smell turned out later to be mostly from the soap and shampoo products in the rooms - which have a peculiar smell - they say aloe, but the fragrence is a bit more cloying than that to me. You get two small soaps, shampoo, conditioner and lotion in little bottles. The soap is very drying, so bring your own if that bothers you.My room was at the end of the hall, and was small, but very clean. The hallway was clear, except for some trays here and there, and someone had left a broken wine glass on the hallway floor that took a day to have cleaned up. The room appointments included the king bed, LCD TV, chest, desk and chair with internet connection access, separate comfy chair, and bathroom. The bed seemed new, and was very comfortable (firm, yet not too hard.) Soft white linens, generous number of pillows, and a mini-coverlet in gold were on the bed. Some hotel pictures with the designer "R" bed pillows were not to be found in this room, but no big deal.The room was a bit hot, so I turned on the older style floor model combo A/C and heater. It worked fine, but was a little loud. Turns out that was a good thing, as each of the two nights I stayed, there was heavy machinery noise from the outside inclusive of rings and beeps that I could hear even over the A/C from 12 mid to around 2 in the morning. Not the hotel's fault - but if you are a light sleeper, recommend ear plugs. I also agree with other posts that you can hear everything in the hallway, from conversations, baby cries, to door knocks, opening and closings, and slams. Thankfully, not too much could be heard in the room from neighbors in their rooms, mostly noise from hallway and outside. (Note the window could open to the outside, but I did not use it.)My neighbors were either a group of goats, or a bunch of wild guys coming in at all hours. Not my business, other than a couple of them banging on my door at 3 in the morning thinking it was their room. I ignored this, and the guys stumbled into their room (after banging that door), and the episode was over.There's a new flat screen LCD TV in the room with fairly good reception, but the higher number channels were fuzzy, and as mentioned in other reviews not a lot of choice of channels - but who spends that much time in the room, anyway?Surprising to me for an older hotel was that there was enough adequate lighting that all worked, and enough mirrors. The room, while small, had a fairly large closet right near the entranceway, with an iron and ironing board available. The overall feel of the room was like staying in grandma's attic room - old, small, clean, layers of cream colored paint and wallpaper, a bit mismatched, a little musty, but mostly cozy and workable. I know it sounds odd, but that was the feeling.The bathroom was very clean, but a bit uninspired. You could see where new tiles had been put in the shower area, with a bowed out curtain bar (nice touch giving more shoulder room), new shower curtain (nice, but did not match decor), a pedestal sink (pretty, but does not give counter space), commode (right next to ancient radiator so little room. and the commode seat was crooked), and two small glass shelves without too much space. The tub had two enamel gouges that someone attempted to repair with enamel paint. Large mirror, with an ugly industrial light, which made the room seem a bit sad and garishly lit. Not good for makeup application. There was a hair dryer, medium wattage - the dryer had a little night light on it, a nice touch. Plenty of clean white towels - but first night no washcloths. TP is cheap and harsh, so bring your own if you are sensitive to same.No coffee maker. No mini-bar. Ice bucket and glasses; soda machines down the hall with ice available. Surprisingly, no NY magazines, maps or tourist publications in the room, you had to ask at the desk or concierge. Checkout can be via TV/phone, but I went to the desk. No problems with my bill. Note that there are a number of city taxes that apply in addition to your room rate per night (almost +$30.)We had a breakfast in the Roosevelt restaurant (mezzanine level just up from the lobby.) Pretty ambience, nice buffet and menu, but EXPENSIVE. There are nearby cheaper places.My overall experience was that this place had all the necessities and is in an incredibly good location and gives pretty good value. Was it amazing? No. Was it clean and a very good value? Yes. Would I stay again for biz? Yes. Would I go for a blow out no expense spared trip into the city? No.

Apr 30 2009 	Go for the Location...not the Service...	Like others have mentioned...the hotel is situated about a 2 minute walk away from grand central station so it is a great location for those who want to take the MTA all the time. The hotel itself is very old, and for how old it is...the rooms are actually not too bad. The building itself has been kept quite nice, and overall is quite clean.Room noise is bad, you can always hear people entering and leaving rooms, and street noise is pretty abundant(poor insulation I guess), but that is not a big deal...being inside Manhattan I didn't expect it to be too quiet.But my overall experience in terms of service here was quite horrible. I called ahead of time to confirm my reservation as we will be arriving late that night...everything was supposedly ok. Once we arrived however the story was different. We had 2 rooms, and one of them was supposed to be a double...but nope...it magically turned to a Single King, and apparently there was no other room available anymore. So we accepted that and would try to find another room the next day. My only requests were to be situated on a higher floor and to be away from the elevators (we booked 1 month in advance)...but nope...we got the fourth floor...and one of the rooms was right in front of the elevator.Thats when it all went downhill...our other party split with us, then got stuck in the elevator for 1.5 hours...being stuck in an elevator is acceptable since things do break down once in a while...but for 1.5 hours was pretty ridiculous, and there was very very poor communication from the outside staff letting us know what was going on. Anyways, after this fiasco, we met the only 'nice' person of our hotel stay...the evening manager...he was quite apologetic and overall very professional.Anytime we needed service at the concierge or the front desk, the staff just seemed rude and did not act like we were customers...we stayed a total of 14 days there between our 2 rooms and the only time we felt there was customer service was with the bellhop and the night service manager, everyone else was just rude. We visited the Grill inside the Hotel for breakfast...the staff there were equally unpleasant; Absolutely no service, they would just stand around and talk to each other...when we say thanks, they never would reply with a welcome or any response for that matter...Also the safe's in both rooms were not operational when we initially checked in. The business center charges you around 30cents a minute for internet with a minimum $3 charge, but the computers are so slow, you spend half the time just waiting for things to load.Be it perhaps we are high maintenance, or just demanding too much...but we would definitely not recommend or repeat even though it was a great value, and great location.

Mar 18 2009 	Fantastic Location Good Hotel Great Holiday	Like many people, I read as many reviews as possible before deciding on a hotel in New York.....some of the reviews on here just have to be ignored. The Roosevelt is a very, very good choice for a week in New York.Firstly, the location. Perfect spot just off Madison Ave. Lovely short walk to Bloomingdales, Times Square, Macy's, Central Park, Empire State Building, Rockerfella Centre, Chrysler Building. If you walk out the front of the hotel and cross the road, there is a door marked Grand Central Station. Within 2 mins you are in the main concourse. Perfect if you need trains/subway.TIP - Turn left out the main entrance on 46th Street and walk 4 blocks (past Met Life Centre on right). The Comfort Diner is a perfect place for breakfast, or lunch, or dinner! Great staff. What us English would descibe as a proper New York diner. I cannot recommend this place highly enough, and really set us up for the day.Second, the hotel and staff. If your the sort of person that gives a hotel rating a 1 star if someone doesn't say hello back to you, then you really need help! Check in was excellent. Arrived 1pm, room not ready. Stored luggage and was told to come back at 3pm. Had a drink in the bar and a local stroll in the snow and got back at 3pm. Room still not ready - BUT, I did not complain, just stayed silent for a few seconds and the lady gave us a free upgrade to a King Room. The room itself wasn't massive, so I would imagine a cozy Queen is very small, BUT it was clean, flatscreen tv, small but fine bathroom with a good shower. No complaints. The bed was excellent. TIP - if you are given a room opposite the lifts, change (as in any hotel). There are no tea/coffee facilities but there is a small coffee shop directly opposite and a Starbucks serving from the hotel bar in the morning.We avoided room service as it looked horrendously over-priced.The lobby is beautiful. It really takes you back to a grand hotel from the 30's. The bar next to the lobby is very busy, but we always found a table. WARNING - Drinks are very expensive. $15 - $20 for a cocktail and just under $10 for a pint. We had a few drinks as it was such a nice location and atmosphere, but I wouldn't advise going on an all day session unless you re-mortgaged the house before you came out.We stayed for seven nights and 2 of the nights had roadworks till past midnight....BUT I'm not going to mark a hotel down for that! Also one night had a big Jewish wedding so there was alot of corridor noise, but again only because we were near the lifts.We had no problem with the staff at all. If you feel someone deserves a tip, give them one. Never at any point did we feel pressured to tip anyone. I would recommend the hotel car back to the airport. That little bit of luxury is a perfect way to round the holiday off, and probably works out the same cost ($55) than the yellow cab ($45 + tip and tolls).The rooms were ok, but like everyone says, the only time you should spend in your room in New York is either getting ready to go out or sleeping.All in all, the hotel and location was the perfect place to spend the week in which I proposed to my girlfriend. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who was staying in New York.

Mar 16 2009 	Excellent Time at the Roosevelt!	My mom, sister and I stayed at the Roosevelt from February 23 - March 1st and really cannot say anything negative about our experience!Our flight arrived at JFK early in the morning and we arrived at the Roosevelt before 8am. Our room was not ready for us at the time, but our luggage was happily taken care of for us and we were invited to return earlier than the regular check-in time should we choose as the front desk agent was sure our room would be ready by 1pm at the latest. I had originally booked a Cozy Queen room as part of an Expedia package as my mom and I had planned on traveling just the two of us, however when my sister decided to come, we called the hotel ahead of time and asked our room to be changed. As we had an extra person travelling with us, I fully expected to pay for the room upgrade, however we weren't charged anything!We had a great room with 2 double beds, clean bathroom and room, plenty of room for our luggage and a nice view of 46th Street. The beds were very comfortable, there was some noise outside at night from the garbage trucks working overtime to keep the streets clean, however all three of us slept very well. All but one morning we started our day by running down to the lounge in the lobby for bagels, fruit and coffee. Very conveinent, the staff were friendly, courteous, lovely.The hotel lobby was absolutely beautiful. Constantly busy as meeting and conferences were going on almost all the time. I never once felt unsafe in the hotel or the city for that matter! The hotel location is superb. With Grand Central just a block away, it's easy to get anywhere from the hotel! Also, at 47th and Madison is an excellent caf, Caf Metro. Highly recommend going there for amazing soups and salads. Perfect if you want to grab some food to take back to the hotel.At no time during our entire stay did I ever feel like I had to tip anyone working at the Roosevelt. We left a few dollars everyday in the room for the maid service, and tipped the Bellmen when they retrieved our luggage for us from storage upon our arrival and when we left the hotel. The gentlemen working outside taking care of the taxi's/towncars helped us out, never implying or indicating a sense of entitlement when it came to tips.I highly recommend the Roosevelt to anyone looking for the quintessential New York experience. I cannot wait to return!

Mar 7 2009 	Best hotel superb clean fantastic location ticks all the boxes for me	We ( 2 best mates ) stayed here at the end of Jan into Feb and what a lovely hotel. The bed was soooo comfy and there was peace and quiet apart from the humming of traffic and honking of taxi horns- very NYC ! Feb 24 2009 	good value clean and comfortable	This was my husband and I's 2nd stay at the Roosevelt. We had previously stayed there for new year's eve 2007-2008 and got upgraded to a king minisuite. There was no chest of drawers which was a bit of a pain so we did have to keep most of our stuff in our suitcases.One thing that amused us was that they had installed a very nice large flatscreen TV, but the wiring was a joke! The hub was just bolted to the middle of the wall and the wires were everywhere.The bathroom was clean and we had a bath/shower, but it did look a little dated compared to other hotels.The best thing about the room was the bed! It was the comfiest bed either of us had ever slept in - both firm and soft at the same time if that's possible?!The room was a great base and because the hotel was so well placed next to Grand Central Station we were able to pop back during the day if we wanted, for a rest and/or a romantic interlude....The hotel was well placed for a quick walk to Times Square, a reasonable stroll to Central Park, and a few minutes to the metro at Grand Central.We did struggle to start with to find nice places for breakfast but eventually found Pershing Square which did delicious breakfasts - recommend the eggs benedict - and the Central Cafe where the salads and the sesame chicken were very good. Beware though - some of the buffet was stone cold!The only criticism we'd have is that the doormen were a little mercenary. We tipped $2 or $3 for every interaction that involved someone carrying our bags - not bad considering the distance was usually only about 3 feet!It was obvious that they all compared notes on who was a good tipper, because when we stored our bags on the last day for a couple hours, the doorman got $2, and when we went to collect them the guy who got them out was reluctant to help and just put them outside the door of the storage cupboard and made no effort to help us take them out the front of the hotel!When we left, we went to hail a yellow taxi back to JFK, which costs a flat fare of $45 (which rises to $60 when you factor in the $5 toll tunnel and a tip). The doorman muscled in and practically bundled us into the hotel limousine, saying that it was a flat fare of $55. Hardly seemed a bargain but this guy wasn't asking - he was telling. Anyway, the limo was fine and I only ended up paying $62 including tip, so there wasn't much in it. Incidentally the driver took a more circuitous route that avoided the toll tunnel, so he saved the $5 there. The journey took a little longer as a result but it wasn't a problem for us.All in all, our stay was very enjoyable and we would definitely go back.

Feb 15 2009 	Good hotel great location	My partner and I traveled to New York in November 2008 and decided to stay at the Roosevelt Hotel after reading reviews on Trip Advisor. The check-in process was fast and easy, people at the reception desk friendly and helpful. The room we stayed in was in very good conditions, not big, but not small neither. The bed was very good, the bathroom was OK and clean. Location was great, within walking distance of the Central Station, 5th Avenue and Times Square. Only downside: the price of drinks at the bar, and of the food at the restaurant. Better off to eat and drink outside the hotel.

Feb 14 2009 	Convenient but typical old NY hotel	The best thing about the Roosevelt is the location right in midtown. Very convenient to Grand Central, Rockefeller Center, and Times Square etc. The rooms are tiny as you would expect. Our window faced a fire escape. Could hardly put our suitcases in the room without tripping over everything. Bed was good though, very comfy. Bathroom okay, no room to put 2 toilet bags.Lift is terrible. Wait for 10 minutes at least. A lot of people enter via the basement and slow everything down. We were on the 12th floor and honestly it's better to walk down if you are not burdened by cases. Very very busy but then it was July so couldn't expect anything else. Room service is patchy. If you have an issue, don't expect to resolve it over the phone. Save yourself the trouble and go down to the lobby and sort it out there.Lobby overcrowded and nowhere to sit. People were queueing for a place to park themselves while they waited for service or the concierge. Again, it was July I know, but that's when you see a hotel at its worst. Staff seemed inured to the chaos. Concierge was very good on the other hand, knew everything about tickets, restaurants, subway etc. This is also an aircrew hotel so sometimes a couple of crews will be checking in and out in front of you. Can't imagine how frustrating it must be for them to stay here, though.Wouldn't want to stay here more than a couple of nights. If you are staying a week or so, bite the bullet and find an apartment hotel or condo for short stays. If we had to stay in that tiny room for a week my partner and I would have murdered each other probably.Bottom line: standard old NY hotel. Great location for tourists. Reasonably priced for what it is. Just don't expect anything special.

Feb 11 2009 	Great location with some faults	My daughter and I stayed at the Roosevelt the weekend of Feb.6-8. The trip was a surprise to celebrate her birthday. We were seeing 2 shows and doing alot of shopping so the location was perfect. We were able to take the airtrain and the subway from JFK to the 5th Ave/53rd St. stop and walk the 8 blocks- very easy (50 minutes). It is also only two blocks to catch the subway at Grand Central to go downtown. I had booked the hotel through Expedia and got a rate of 118 (this included the taxes), which is why I chose it! The room I booked was a "cozy queen" but we were upgraded to a king upon arrival. The room was on the 7th floor with a view of the interior (this reduced noise at night, although this is a quiet area of midtown). Our room wasn't big but all we did was sleep there. There was no coffee maker but Blake and Todds across the street had great breakfasts and coffee. The bathroom was small and the tub didn't drain well but we managed just fine. Our room wasn't cleaned on Saturday even though we were gone from 9:30 until 5:00. Since we were only there 2 nights I wasn't too concerned about it, and I didn't feel bad not leaving a tip for the maid. The concierge held our bags on Sunday for us for no charge. I have stayed at the Parc Central, Warwick, Intercontinental, and Wellington and for the price this was perfect. I would much rather have the money in my pocket to spend on other things while in the city.

Feb 11 2009 	Excellent!	This hotel was absolutely brilliant! I was nervous initially as some of the reviews on here are a little negative.Check in was prompt and friendly, although as it was for my 21st birthday i think we were going to be offered an upgrade, until they realised that what booked through expedia. what difference that makes???? i dont know!But the room given was lovely and we were on the 12th floor and far far away from the lifts so it was soooo quiet. However i did take earplugs just incase. The bed linen and bathroom was clean and it was of a really good size too. Obviously you need to be in reasonably good shape to do that but it worked well for us. We didnt seem to have a probem with staff expecting tips, however do make sure that you carry lots of $1 bills, otherwise you may find yourself giving $5 for a guy to carry 2 bags down three stairs like we did!!

Feb 10 2009 	all around bad experience	I have traveled to NY several times and stayed in many different classes of hotels, but I can say that the Roosevelt was the first time that I was ever Unpleasantly surprised at the condition of the property, relative to what I paid.Short review: NOT RECOMMENDED if you plan to pay via debit card, gorgeous lobby, RUDE staff, filthy guest areas, cramped rooms, broken equipment (windows, A/C, etc.), you will be asked directly for tips by nearly everyone on hotel staff, NOT WORTH THE PRICE. Full review: "You get what you pay for" goes double in Manhattan, but seeing as how I had paid over $200 per night and was staying for 5 days, I expected much more than I received from my trip (2/5-2/9/2009). That being said, I may have felt better about staying in an outdated room if I had paid a lot less, but I still wouldn't recommend this hotel to anyone based on the terrible service.It was partially my fault for not reading reviews before I booked the hotel, which all seem to echo my same problems. I think that a lot of the reviewers on Trip Advisor must have stayed in my same room!Pros:- location, proximity to Grand Central/Midtown Manhattan- beautiful lobby- comfortable bedCons: - doormen are pushy and rude and will demand a tip for opening your taxi door (I saw this happen to other people too and when one person apologized that he didn't have any cash, the doorman gave him directions to the nearest ATM and told him what his shift hours were!)- the arcade (shopping mall) that is on the ground floor of the hotel closes in the early evening and after it closes, there is no elevator service from the 1st floor. You HAVE to climb/carry your bags up 2 flights of stairs. (note for travelers who have problems with stairs)- no offer of assistance with taking luggage up the stairs. For me, it wasn't a problem since I only had small bags, but if someone had larger luggage, they'd have to make several trips- front desk staff was very rude, right from the start. I made my reservation by telephone, and when I checked in it looked like I had made 2 reservations and initially the woman at the front desk wanted to charge me a 'late cancellation fee' for not needing the 2nd room. After standing my ground and refusing to pay for it, she relented and checked me in. - I was planning to use my debit card for payment and initially was unable to because the hotel REQUIRES a pre-authorization of the total room & tax amount plus $100 per day "for incidentals". In my case, this was over $1400, and I have a daily transaction limit on my debit card of $500, so I couldn't use it. **the reason I include this as a "con" is that I worked in the travel industry for many years and I currently travel 10+ times per year and I have NEVER seen a hotel require a pre-auth for the total amount, plus incidentals. Typically, they pre-auth 1 night room & tax and the guest has a right to have the ability to charge any incidentals "blocked" on their account (this means that they can't use the phone for long distance, order pay-per-view, etc.).** - due to the pre-authorization issues above, I had to use a separate credit card for the "guarantee" and make staggered payments every couple of days on my debit card to keep each charge under $500 [this is my bank's policy, which may not be a problem for other people]. However, each time I would make a payment, the front desk staff would act like it was the most difficult thing in the world. One woman even asked me to not do it and instead go to a bank and withdraw all the cash that I could and pay that way so that she didn't have to do a computer entry. That wasn't an option, so she grudgingly made the payment but was very hostile about it and at the end threw the card on the counter at me and walked away. I've never had anyone give me such a hard time about giving them money!- ALSO, each time I made a payment, the woman told me, I would have to be pre-authorized AGAIN so that a separate hold would be put on my credit card. Each time, it would be $1400, regardless of how long I had already been there. For me, this wasn't a problem, but for anyone else trying the same thing, they'd need to be able to charge $1400 x 3 (number of payments I made with my debit card) = $4200. This does not make ANY sense and no one could explain it.- Room problem: key reader in door would only work intermittently, needed card to be swiped 15-20 times before it would read- Room problem: A/C was extremely noisy (sounded like a jackhammer). Also, A/C is in the window, so curtains had to be kept open to get the cool air into the room.- Room problem: dresser was at the foot of the bed, about 10" from the mattress. Cannot pull suitcase through this space. I also hit my hip/leg on the sharp corners several times- Room problem: bathtub wouldn't hold water, drain seal was broken. Very low water pressure, took about 20 minutes to fill up bath tub (drained out with stopper closed in about 5 minutes). - Room problem: TV static, unable to watch any programs- I called the manager on duty and explained the problems with my room and was scrutinized. After having to justify why I needed a room change, I was told that there were "no rooms available" but that I could check out at noon and I would need to leave my luggage at the bell desk and they would see what they could do. IF there was a room, it would not be ready until after 4pm and I might have to take a smoking room.- At this point, I wanted to just change hotels, but the cancellation policy is 24 hours so I'd already have to pay for the current day PLUS they charge $75 fee for cancelling once your stay has started. Again, I have NEVER heard of this at any other hotel.- Bellmen unhelpful and pushy - There was a man sitting at the bell desk who did not actually help anyone, but instead would just point to where you should stand until someone else came along. The man who came eventually was a very old man with a pronounced limp. He was obviously in no condition to haul my bags, so I carried them myself (up a set of 3 stairs) to the closet where the bags are stored. Once I was given my claim check, both the old man and the man at the desk hit me up for tips, even though neither had done ANYTHING whatsoever. I felt obligated to tip them both, since I would be back in a few hours to collect my bags and didn't want them to get "lost" in the closet.- Housekeeping staff needs to watch their foul language. 2 of the housekeeping ladies were talking in the hall (I passed right next to them and they very clearly saw me) about a guest who had the Do Not Disturb sign on their door and said "if that [-] doesn't want her [-] room cleaned right now then [-] her and she can wait until tomorrow because I'm going on my my [-] break!"- Got a new room, but it was even worse. I was basically downgraded to a smaller room with the same aesthetic problems and fewer functional ones. A/C did work, but was actually a window unit with a poor patchwork seal. So the noise from the city poured in and the curtains had to be kept open to feel the air. Card reader in the door was spotty. - Hallways were FILTHY. The edges of the rugs had not been vacuumed in a very long time -- the dark green carpets showed the dust too well. Entire hallway smelled like musty garbage.- Rooms were very dingy and dusty, not well-cleaned. The crown moldings looked horribly beat-up and the wallpaper was peeling. - elevators were slow and rickety. I feel fortunate that we didn't get trapped!- Would have been nice: if the lights in the hallway weren't so bright. They shine in the room at night under the door and through peep hole and lighten up the whole place. (this is in addition to all the city light coming in the window because the curtains can't be closed).- Would have been nice: if there were more pillow options. The pillows on the bed were all extra firm, and I ended up with a neck ache every morning. I would NOT ever stay again. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who plans to stay for several days. If there was a tremendous deal, say $120 a night, and you're only there for a day or two, then it might be a fair trade for the hassle. But the staff here really dragged down my entire trip this time.

Feb 10 2009 	Rooms Are Basic	My wife went for a conference and I came up a couple of days later. The rooms are a nice size but the amenities are few. No Coffee maker in the room. The ironing board was never put away and the beds were just straightened, not changed. The bath room is small. There is no separate vanity and no counter space. It is a pedestal sink. Feb 10 2009 	Fab location	We stayed at the Roosevelt Hotel from 2nd Feb till the 7th Feb 2009. We got a taxi from JFK which including tolls came to just under $50. We arrived at the hotel at about 4.30-5pm joined the small queue to check in. Check in was really easy just give your name show some photo ID (passport) and they need a credit card to authorise for any incidentals. I only had my bank card so handed that over but nothing was charged. We were booked into a cozy room but were upgraded at check in to a superior room. Sounds good but the only difference is the room is slightly bigger and has 2 double beds. The beds were really comfy if not slightly small , but we have a big bed at home so could just be us. The bathroom was compact but perfectly fine. The hotel is incredibly warm so we had to have the air on nearly all the time but you get used to it. Our room was on the 16th floor it was cleaned everyday and we had fresh towels everyday. This hotel is ideal if you are going to be out exploring New york everything is within walking distance and grand central station is just across the road. We didn't eat in the hotel although it did look nice we ate out as it was cheaper. When it was time to leave we checked out which just involved us handing over our door key and asked the doorman to order us a car, we got a lincoln town car back to JFK which was $60 including tip.

Feb 3 2009 	Fabulous location and great hotel!	My partner and I stayed here from the 17th Jan for a week. It was a perfect place to stay!The only drawback was on the last day, they stored our luggage, and when we went to get them to go to the airport, They said "this service is free, however a gratuatary tip is often given" All her did was carry my case down one flight of stairs (3 in total) and then made to feel uncomfortable when we were resting in the lobby afterwards and as we left.Anyway, DONT LET THAT PUT YOU OFF......The hotel is in a perfect location for Times Square, Central Park, 5th Avenue, Bloomingdales, Macy's and the main sights! The only time we did was to recharge batteries on the camara and legs.The maids were friendly and always said hello and reception staff were pleasent, so i do not know what other people are on about!Ask for a high floor, then you get better views. We had a view of the rockerfella.

Feb 2 2009 	Positive:Location----Negative:Staff	There are a few good things about this hotel. The location and the breakfast buffet are both terrific. You won't have to rely on the subway or taxi to get you anywhere. So much is within walking distance...the Minskoff Theater where Lion King is playing, Times Square, Rockefeller Center, etc. The lobby of this hotel is jaw-dropping gorgeous.There's a great pizza place on 55 W. 45th St. called Little Italy pizza parlor. Delicious!!Also a very good Irish Pub down the street.Like most New York hotels-- the room is small, but even the Superior rooms are very small at the Roosevelt and the bathrooms are uncomfortably cramped and in need of a renovation. Despite the many elevators, they are slow and cramped full. If you're on the 6th or 7th floor, be prepared to wait awhile...as there are about 19 floors in this hotel. Food from Room service is not good and they will not call you if something is not available, they just substitute something else. I'm not a picky eater, and it was not a good meal especially for the price.Perhaps the most disappointing thing about the Roosevelt Hotel is the staff. The room size and condition can be forgiven, but not the overall attitude of the people working there. There are many people who just can't be pleased and I'm sure it's not easy for staff to deal with that day in and day out. However, I believe most people like myself, just appreciate a friendly greeting and people who actually take pride in their job and place of work. You don't see this at the Roosevelt. Even the people working the breakfast buffet...although efficient, they never smiled and seemed miserable.Front desk service is slow as molasses and not organized. Bell hops are too busy chatting amongst themselves to help you unless you're dressed in a fur and will tip well. Maids hover and rush you...asking when you are checking out.Just read some of the reviews below...and these comments are just from January alone....."Cranky door man, staff not very friendly, Worst Customer service EVER!, staff not very helpful and always in a bad mood."Whoever runs the show at the Roosevelt should thank their lucky stars for their location, because that is one of the few things the hotel has going for it.

Jan 26 2009 	Ask yourself what you want in a NYC hotel and this place ticks every box.	I just got back from 6 nights and I am so glad I booked it and didn't listen to the negative reviews on here. Ask yourself what you want from a NYC hotel and the Roosevelt ticks all the boxes. 1] Location: you don't need to use the subway. This place is within walking distance of all the major attractions. 2] Safety: It is located within a busy area at the heart of NY so no matter the time you always feel safe.3] Room size: The rooms are fair for NY where everything is generally small. If you will use it as a crash pad it will suit your needs completely.4] Staff: Generally pleasant. Others have complained about the cleaning staff but I found them to be outstanding. You also never get pressured to leave the room. If you have a don't disturb sign and leave your room late make sure you put the please clean my room sign when you leave. How else are the staff to know you have gone?5] Tipping: I never felt pressured into giving tips. Staff asked if you required assistance and obviously you tip if you get help. But if you don't want help simply say no.

Jan 26 2009 	Convenient location	First the demerits of the hotel : Room cleanup was abit late daily though, once I waited til 3pm and my room wasn't cleaned up yet. Jan 25 2009 	Decent Midtown Hotel	The Roosevelt Hotel is great if you are looking for a decently priced hotel in midtown Manhattan. Jan 23 2009 	Great hotel and location	Excellent hotel, great location. old and classy reception. The room we stayed in were a bit worn out, however the hotel made up with plenty of old charm.

Jan 15 2009 	unsatisfactory service	We were really excited to go to the roosevelt for the night, we only stayed one night, we being me and my boyfriend. Upon arriving there we had to queue for 20 minutes in order to check in. This alone would have been okay but upon finally checking in at around 7pm we were told are room was still not ready. With little choice in the matter we left our bags with the concierge and went for dinner and a walk we came back an hour and a half later. There was only one other couple in the queue in front of us yet we were stood there for 30 minutes this time and slowly the queue built up behind us, meanwhile they have only 2 people on reception only one of whom is dealing with check ins. What made it worse was some people just walked up passed the queue and the staff on reception served them before all the people who had been waiting there. Anyway we finally checked in and found are room and just wanted to have a bath. Loan behold the bath plug was not airtight so after waiting 10 minutes for the water to get hot we ran our bath only to find shortly after all the water to be draining out. Naturally we called reception and were told after our evening of waiting we would have to wait 30-45 minutes for someone to come fix our bath. The man came and went to fix our bath and we proceeded to run one again only to find the man had not fixed the problem anyway we called again and after another 15 minutes we had our bath fixed. Unfortunately at this point we were both too exhausted to enjoy it. Overall it seems the roosevelt needs to be more efficient and reduce waiting time as it is the last thing people want to face after travelling.
